COVID-19 Overview Shinydashboard

shinyapp.Rmd
library(covid19shiny)

This vignette is intended for the usage of covid19shiny package. It explains how to run the shiny application which illustrates the overview of Coronavirus state in the world and describes the functions contained inside the package, as well as guidelines for its use.

The package uses data sourced from tidycovid19 package created by Joachim Gassen by using the download_merged_data function, alongside with countries.csv file taken from Google Developers and Shapefile taken from thematicmapping.org. It is built by using the shiny and shinydashboard package to provide users with an interactive dashboard, exploring the state of the Coronavirus pandemic in the world. The purpose of the shinydashboard is to provide useful insights regarding the state of Coronavirus worldwide and explore deeper into it.

Installing the package

Before using the package, it must firstly be installed from GitHub.

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("etc5523-2020/r-package-assessment-helenevangelinaa")

Running the application

After loading library(covid19shiny), the shiny application could be launched by using the following code:

launch_app()

Datasets inside the package

There are some datasets inside the package that can be used. Firstly, covid19wrangled is the wrangled version of the data taken from download_merged_data from tidycovid19 package. Variables included in the dataset and more detailed information could be viewed by ?covid19shiny::covid19wrangled.

To call the dataset, just run: covid19wrangled. Here is an example of how to use the dataset:

head(covid19wrangled)
#> # A tibble: 6 x 7
#>   country     date       confirmed deaths recovered region     population
#>   <chr>       <date>         <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>           <dbl>
#> 1 Afghanistan 2020-01-22         0      0         0 South Asia   38041754
#> 2 Afghanistan 2020-01-23         0      0         0 South Asia   38041754
#> 3 Afghanistan 2020-01-24         0      0         0 South Asia   38041754
#> 4 Afghanistan 2020-01-25         0      0         0 South Asia   38041754
#> 5 Afghanistan 2020-01-26         0      0         0 South Asia   38041754
#> 6 Afghanistan 2020-01-27         0      0         0 South Asia   38041754

The second dataset, covid19total presents the summary of COVID-19 cases per country, showing total confirmed cases, total deaths and total recovered cases of a country alongside with other information, which is obtained from the covid19qrangled previously explained combined with the countries.csv dataset taken from Google Developers. More information: ?covid19shiny::covid19total.

head(covid19total)
#> # A tibble: 6 x 9
#>   country confirmed deaths recovered region population latitude longitude
#>   <chr>       <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>       <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl>
#> 1 Afghanâ€¦     40141   1488     33561 "Soutâ€¦   38041754     33.9     67.7 
#> 2 Angola       7462    241      3022 "Sub-â€¦   31825295    -11.2     17.9

#> 4 Andorra      3377     59      2057 "Euroâ€¦      77142     42.5      1.60
#> 5 Unitedâ€¦    114387    459    106354 "Middâ€¦    9770529     23.4     53.8 
#> 6 Argentâ€¦    979119  26107    791174 "Latiâ€¦   44938712    -38.4    -63.6 
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: caseper10000 <dbl>

worldshp is a world shape file needed to create a map.

# worldshp
 leaflet(worldshp) %>% addTiles() %>%
      addProviderTiles(providers$Stamen.Toner) %>%
      addPolygons(stroke = FALSE,
                  smoothFactor = 0.4,
                  fillOpacity = 0.7, 
                  fillColor = ~palpolygon(covid19total$caseper10000)) %>%
      addLegend(values =~ covid19total$caseper10000, pal = palpolygon, title = "Cases per 10,000") %>%
      addCircles(data = filterdata(),
                 ~longitude, 
                 ~latitude, 
                 weight = 1,
                 radius = ~(filterdata()$confirmed)^(1/4)*10000,
                 popup = ~as.character(filterdata()$country),
                 color = "#7777",
                 fillColor = ~pal(filterdata()$confirmed), 
                 fillOpacity = 0.6,
                 label = lapply(labs, htmltools::HTML)) %>%
      setView(40, 40, zoom = 1.45)

Functions

Alongside with datasets, the package also contains functions which are created to minimise duplication in the code and make it easy for users to create the contents. - selectInput01 function produces the selectInput from shiny based on the inputs provided. The format is selectInput01(id, choices in where id refers to the id name of the selectInput and choices refers to the values of a datasetâ€™s column wanted to be put into the selectInput.

updateSelectInput(session, "country", selected = country)
  • dailyplot would create a line graph illustrating either the daily confirmed cases, daily death, or daily recovered according to the inputs specified. The format is dailyplot(input_function, input_name, variable_name) in where input_function refers to the input resulted from the selectInput (e.g.Â input$country). The input variable_name would change the y-axis of the line graph to represent the variable specified. variable_name in this case could be daily_confirmed, daily_death or daily_recovered.
dailyplot(input$country, "death", "daily_death")

The dailyplot function will create the following graph, which will be updated based on user input:

  • covidtable would produce a table by using the DT package based on the specified dataset. Fomat is covidtable(data).
covidtable(covid19total)
  • Finally, launch_app would run the shiny application showing the overview of COVID-19 in the world which allows users to interact and explore the state of the Coronavirus pandemic.
launch_app()

How to use the app?

The application is a shinydashboard providing visualisations of the state of COVID-19 which allows users to explore the data and gain meaningful insights. User-interactions are provided so that the visualisations can be updated based on inputs. There are two tabs: 1. Map and Table contains a map and summary table 2. Figures contains the plots

First tab

  • The choropleth map combined with proportional symbol map illustrates the number of confirmed cases around the world.
  • The summary table shows the total confirmed cases, total death and total recovered for each country.

These two visualisations can be updated by using the drop-down menu and slider input.

Second tab

  • Figure 1 shows a time-series plot of overall trend of confirmed cases by country, coloured by region.
  • Figures on the second row illustrates the line graphs of daily confirmed cases, daily deaths, and daily recovered and the summary of overall COVID-19 trend.

Drop-down menus, clickable buttons, as well as clickable map are provided in the second tab to allow user-interactions.

More detailed on how to use the app can be found on the Instructions tab of the dashboard.
